awd_titl_txt: SBP: Consequences of Attributing Discrimination to Implicit Bias
awd_abstract_narration:
Implicit bias training is being used by companies, police departments, and educational institutions to decrease discrimination based on race, gender, and other social categories and thereby to potentially help increase the diversity of their employees. By some estimates, diversity training costs nearly $8 billion a year, but there is little evidence that diversity training is effective at reducing discrimination. It is important to examine how people make sense of and respond to the many acts of discrimination that are attributed to implicit bias. Implicit biases are often thought to be beyond conscious awareness and recent research has found that people tend to hold those who discriminate less accountable if their discriminatory acts are assumed to stem from their implicit biases rather than explicit biases. Across fourteen studies, this project will discover for whom, when, and how this reduced accountability for discrimination attributed to implicit bias is most likely to occur. The project examines whether attributing discrimination to implicit bias affects the extent to which people think it is possible to overcome these forms of prejudice. The research also measures the emotions and behavioral consequences arising from these processes. The research will shed light on how increased awareness of implicit biases may actually produce reduced accountability for some acts of discrimination. The long-term aim of the project is to help produce more effective interventions to reduce societal discrimination. 

Many researchers and laypeople presume that educating the public about implicit bias will galvanize support to combat its discriminatory consequences.  Yet there is reason to expect that greater awareness of implicit bias may actually reduce the extent to which people hold others accountable for acts of discrimination that are attributed to it. This project integrates research from moral cognition and social psychology to examine how people reason about and respond to reports of discriminatory behavior attributed to implicit attitudes. Specifically, this research investigates the hypothesis that because implicit processes are assumed to be beyond conscious awareness, people often hold those who discriminate less accountable for even clearly intentional behaviors when they are attributed to implicit attitudes and beliefs. The research will inform current models of moral responsibility and offer a reconsideration of the question of who is or should be responsible for implicit bias. This research will also consider additional outcomes of implicit bias attributions, including their effects on emotions, perceptions of discrimination, and willingness to work to combat discrimination and inequity. Because a great deal of discrimination is rooted in implicit forms of bias, a small but reliable reduced accountability for implicit bias effect could be highly consequential. The tendency to attribute discriminatory acts to implicit bias may paradoxically reduce the willingness to sanction those who discriminate, with the result of increasing rather than decreasing societal tolerance for discrimination and its effects.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated whether and why people hold others less accountable for discriminatory behavior when the behavior is attributed to their implicit (unconscious) biases and beliefs, compared with their explicit (conscious) biases and beliefs. Across a series of experiments, we find compelling evidence that this “reduced accountability for implicit bias” effect is indeed observed for discrimination based on a broad set of social dimensions (political bias, age-bias, gender-bias, etc.), and across a range of judgements, decisions, and behaviors (e.g., treatment of patients by doctors, managers’ treatment of employees, bank officers’ lending decisions, etc.). Further, both people who share a relevant group membership with the perpetrators of the discrimination (and, thus, may be especially sympathetic to them), as well as those who share a relevant group membership with the victims of the discrimination, reduce their judgments of accountability for discrimination attributed to the perpetrator’s implicit compared with explicit biases.

We find that part of the reason why this effect emerges is because of the outsized influence of perceived intentionality for harm in judgments of culpability. In other words, people tend to punish wrongdoing more severely when they believe perpetrators intended to cause harm, compared to when the harm was accidental or even negligent. People appear to use this logic when reasoning about discriminatory acts, judgments, and decisions. In other words, allegedly being unaware of one’s biased beliefs is interpreted as engaging in differential behavior toward individuals based on a relevant group membership (gender, age, etc.) unintentionally. And, as a result, people are held less accountable for discrimination that is attributed their implicit, rather than explicit, biases. Of course, in reality, it is nearly impossible to discern one clear source of any individual’s or group of individuals’ discriminatory behaviors and, thus, a willingness to reduced perpetrator culpability when the discrimination is attributed to implicit bias may ultimately make it difficult to ensure that organizations actual operate in ways that are not tainted by the types of social biases that are both sub-optimal for their performance, but also illegal.

Interestingly, consistent with the finding that both people who share a group membership with the perpetrators of the discrimination and those who share a group membership with the victims reduce their judgments of accountability for discrimination said to be born of implicit bias, efforts to focus individuals’ attention on the harms incurred by victims does not affect the overall reduced accountability effect. In other words, shifting people’s focus and attention away from the intentionality (i.e., likely mental state) of the perpetrator and direct it toward the harm incurred by the victim(s) has no effect on the extent to which they reduce their judgments of culpability for discrimination that is attributed to the implicit, compared with explicit, bias of the perpetrator. In other words, the reduced accountability for implicit bias effect is robust, reliable, and reproducible.

In addition to these findings regarding culpability for discrimination born of implicit, rather than explicit, bias, several experiments also suggest that people reduce the extent to which they hold individuals accountable for discrimination that stems from their decision to use an algorithm to aid their decision-making. In other words, managers are held more accountable for the discriminatory judgments they produce when those judgments are thought to stem from their own explicit (and in some cases implicit) biases, compared to when the discriminatory judgments are thought to stem from the manager’s use of (what turns out to be) a biased algorithm. This research suggests that algorithmic bias may be especially prone to result in significant harm with no clear perpetrator to hold accountable and, perhaps also, few clear avenues to redress the wrongdoing and/or repair the harm.

Taken together, the research pursued in this project offers important insights regarding how people may be responding to recent scientific and media reports of the roles of implicit bias and even more recently algorithmic bias in perpetuating any number of cases of discrimination. Understanding how people make sense of different types of bias and, thus, potential sources of discriminatory outcomes is important, especially as they strive to both avoid engaging in discrimination themselves and/or being the targets of discrimination.  Further, these findings are especially important as organizations attempt to engage in efficient decision-making practices while also treating employees, clients, and other stakeholders fairly, irrespective of their social characteristics.
